newsitem.title: USA: U.S. spot resids mostly hold, helped by gas, crude.
newsitem.headline: U.S. spot resids mostly hold, helped by gas, crude.

text.p: U.S. spot residual fuel prices mostly held steady Friday in lackluster, pre-holiday trade, underpinned by firmer NYMEX natgas futures and relatively stable crude despite the lack of utility demand, sources said.

"Low sulphur feels pretty good. There may be a little demand into Florida, but there's no aggressive buying interest," said one cash trader, noting high sulphurs may be poised to fall if rumored European barrels arrive.
New York Harbor physical one percent was unchanged at $16.50-75 a barrel, with June one percent paper quoted off a quarter at about $17 on slightly softer crude, traders said.
NYH 0.3 percent high pour notionally inched into the low-$17 area but traders saw little upside with no real underlying utility demand.
High sulphurs in New York notionally were steady, but talk of cargoes from Europe kept buyers wary. NYH 2.2 percent was still talked near $15, traders said.
At the U.S. Gulf, one percent also was little changed at $15.75-16.00, while three percent slipped 25-50 cents to about the $14.50 area.

New York city gate weekend gas prices eased slightly to the low-$2.40s/mmBtu, or $15.25 a barrel equivalent. Gas at Henry Hub, the NYMEX delivery point, also lost some ground to about $2.19/mmBtu, or $13.80 a barrel.
